Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat with my stepfamily lighting up with reminders about tonight’s dinner. My stepdad had emphasized how important it was for me to be there, to show I was really part of the family now. I could almost hear my mom’s voice, gentle but firm, telling me how much it would mean to her if I joined. But my phone buzzed again—this time, a message from Mia. She’d barely slept since her brother died, and her words were raw, desperate: “Can you come over? I just… I don’t want to be alone tonight.”

My chest tightened. I wanted to be there for Mia, to hold her and let her cry, to be the boyfriend she needed. But I also knew how fragile things were at home, how much my presence at dinner mattered to my new family. I felt pulled in two directions, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
